On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 3:04 AM, <wiki1000@ya=
hoo.com> wrote:

>
>
> Hello,
>
>
> The "affordance" (way to be used)  of a=
 given Server IRI is described by
> the Content-Type header returned by OPT=
IONS, but
>
> apparently nothing is provided to publish the media type of r=
esources
> which may be POSTed to the IRI.
>
> The only "well known" ways a=
re, to my knowledge:
>
> - a return HTML FORM containing "accept" attribute=
s
>
> - an ATOM payload (there is only one media type, easy)
>
>
> In a sim=
ilar way, using a Link (or Link-Template) header only allows the
> "type" p=
arameter describing what the IRI may return on GET, and not what it
> may a=
ccept with POST.
>
>
> Is it totally meaningless to consider the use of the=
 Accept header in a
> server response to list the media types of resources =
which may be POSTed to
> the IRI?
>
> It could be also considered to consid=
er the user of "accept=3D" attribute in
> the syntax of the Link header for=
 the same purpose.
>
>
> Since this idea seems trivial and is (apparently) =
not used, it is perhaps
> silly: what do you think ?
>
>
>
>
> 
>

--047d7bfcf91407e16c04f8f6de8f

<br><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 3:04=
 AM,  <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:wiki1000@..." target=3D=
"_blank">wiki1000@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote class=3D"g=

eft:1ex">








        




<div>





<br><br>




<p><span>Hello,=C2=
=A0</span></p><p><span><br></span></p><p><span>The "affordance" (=
way to be used) =C2=A0of a given Server IRI is described by the Content-Typ=
e header returned by OPTIONS, but</span></p><p><span>apparently nothing is =
provided to publish the media type of resources which may be POSTed to the =
IRI.</span></p>

<p><span>The only "well known" ways are, to my k=
nowledge:=C2=A0</span></p><p><span>- a return HTML FORM containing "ac=
cept" attributes</span></p><p><span>- an ATOM payload (there is only o=
ne media type, easy)</span></p>

<p><br></p><p>In a similar way, using a Li=
nk (or Link-Template) header only allows the "type" parameter des=
cribing what the IRI may return on GET, and not what it may accept with POS=
T.=C2=A0</p><p><br></p><p>Is it totally meaningless to consider the use of =
the Accept header in a server response to list the media types of resources=
 which may be POSTed to the IRI?=C2=A0</p>

<p>It could be also considered =
to consider the user of "accept=3D" attribute in the syntax of th=
e Link header for the same purpose.=C2=A0</p><p><br></p><p>Since this idea =
seems trivial and is (apparently) not used, it is perhaps silly: what do yo=
u think ?=C2=A0</p>

<p><span><br></span></p>





<br>


<br>




<div wid=
th=3D"1" style=3D"color:white;clear:both"></div>



</blockquote></div><br>=
</div>
